answer.para: Mr Kerr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Denison has been warned. The member for Denison!

—to try and break Patrick, if they had decided to abandon their restrictive work practices, if years ago they had recognised that no group in the Australian community can possibly be entitled to this sort of privileged treatment, unhindered and unharmed, for years into the future, if they had not set out to destroy Patrick, they would not be in the predicament they are in today.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I go to relevance. These are workers operating at world's best practice and with no strikes, and you have sacked them. Why?
—The Leader of the Opposition will raise his point of order. The Leader of the Opposition is not to engage in debate across the chamber during question time.
—They are responsible for their own predicament.
—Fancy having to listen to you when—
—The member for Denison has already been warned.

—They are to blame because if they had behaved sensibly and if they had recognised that no group in the community is entitled to immunity in this competitive era, if they had accepted the responsibility and if they had accepted the business circumstances of other businessmen and business women in the Australian community, they would not be where they are now. The Leader of the Opposition and others can ask as many questions as they choose.
—We will.

—Very good! Nothing will alter the fact that the members of the MUA have created their own predicament. That has not been generated by anybody else. Their own conduct is the reason why they are in the situation that they are at present. I can only say again that I am very proud to lead a government which has changed the law to give Australia the hope, years and years afterwards, of a competitive and productive waterfront that will generate thousands of jobs and will promote the export interests of the entire Australian nation.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. In the light of recent events on the waterfront, what action has the Reith government taken to ensure that the Maritime Union does not shut down the rest of the waterfront—

—Members of the opposition will remain silent. I would suggest that some of the members in this place might do well to see a rebroadcast of proceedings to look at their own behaviour. It does not enhance their reputation.

interjection.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Honourable members will remain silent. I ask the honourable member for Kooyong to put his question.

—I ask the Treasurer: in the light of recent events on the waterfront, what action has the government taken to ensure that the Maritime Union does not shut down the rest of the waterfront where they still enjoy privileged monopoly coverage? What legislative safeguards has the government enacted to protect Australian industry from rogue unions which wish to strike in sympathy with the Maritime Union of Australia?
—I call the Treasurer. The Treasurer will resume his place. If members of the opposition are silent, I will again be able to call one of their number.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the question was addressed to the Treasurer. No aspect of the question comes under the responsibilities of the Treasurer.

—Members of this House do know that the Treasurer has wide responsibilities. However, I point out to the Treasurer that the responsibilities for this specifically lie with the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business and I would suggest that he identify his responsibility in the question and nobody else's.

—Certainly, Mr Speaker, and just to inform you and also the member, as Treasurer I am responsible for the competition provisions of the Trade Practices Act, including the secondary boycott provisions, and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, responsible for enforcing secondary boycott provisions. The secondary boycott provisions were first introduced into the Trade Practices Act in 1974 by the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, the Hon. John Howard. That was some 25 years ago when the then Fraser government was leading in the area of competition, and it was not until the late 1980s and 1990s, during the dark years of the Hawke government, that the provisions were actually taken out of the Trade Practices Act. One of the great achievements of this government was to put back into the act the provisions preventing secondary boycotts, and I want to pay credit to the minister for industrial relations, Mr Reith, who presided over the amendments that brought back those important reforms—
—The Howard law.

—That brought back the Howard law of all those years ago. He couldn't do it on his own, could he? He would be the first to acknowledge that he was assisted in that task by Mrs Cheryl Kernot, of the Labor Party, in bringing back those secondary boycott provisions. We would like to thank Mrs Cheryl Kernot for the services that she has provided in bringing those secondary boycott provisions back.

answer.para: A secondary boycott provision provides that no person can extend a dispute between the primary employer and employee into other industries. The Trade Practices Act is monitored by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, for which the Treasurer is responsible, and it has a watching brief over the waterfront industrial situation at the moment, including any activities which could be taken to extend this dispute into other industries.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission warned the Australian Workers Union last week, in response to threats to shut down Australia's oil industry in support of the maritime union, that it would be taking action if the AWU breached the act. Fines for breaching the secondary boycott provisions of the act are $750,000, and in addition a person in breach of the act can also be responsible for damages.

In 1995 the Industry Commission, in its report The growth and revenue implications of Hilmer and related reforms, estimated that benchmarking Australian ports to Australian best practice would generate an increase in GDP of about $1 billion. That report was in fact welcomed by some of the thinkers in the parliament. When the Industry Commission report came down assessing the benefits of competition policy and saying, inter alia, that it would add $1 billion to GDP in Australia, it was warmly welcomed by none other than the member for Werriwa. The member for Werriwa, the thinker of the Labor Party, got up in the adjournment debate on that very report and said this:

I am the strongest possible advocate of the introduction of competition policies throughout the Australian economy. You can therefore imagine my pleasure this morning to read in the Australian the findings of the draft Industry Commission report on the benefits of the introduction of Hilmer reforms.

So the thinker of the Labor Party endorsed the benefits of competition which will come about as a result of getting improved performance on the waterfront. The Centre for International Economics in 1995 estimated that a 10 per cent increase in productivity of the sea transport services sector would increase real GDP by about $1 billion. Wouldn't that be a great thing for the country?

One of the great things about reforming the ports and wharves in this country, about increasing competition, will be adding to national wealth, adding to job creation, adding to exports, adding to the opportunity to get foreign debt under control and adding to the improvements in the Australian economy. The government congratulates those who have taken steps to achieve best practice on the waterfront. Back in 1991 the then minister for—I do not know what he was minister for—Mr Beazley was boasting about the need for waterfront reform.

talk.start.para: —Employment.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker. It has become a habit of the government not to refer to people properly in this place, and I would ask you to act to deal with this at this stage of the game.
—In that instance I think he was referring to a previous incarnation, but I draw the Treasurer's attention to the requirement that he call members by their right titles.
—The current Leader of the Opposition, I think then the employment minister, said this:

answer.para: If we can change industrial relations on the waterfront, it ain't too hard for you to get rid of feral pigs. Back to the feral pigs, old son—the waterfront has been fixed.
That is what he said in 1992. In 1992 the waterfront had not been fixed. The waterfront will be fixed as a result of this government's action, and that will be in Australia's interests.

talk.start.para: —My question is again to the Prime Minister. Isn't it a fact that at the overwhelming majority of the 17 ports where Patrick Stevedoring workers were sacked last night there has been no recent industrial action? What evidence do you have to support your claim that workers in ports such as Burnie, Townsville, Darwin, Port Kembla, Newcastle, Cairns, Mackay and Bell Bay have engaged in persistent industrial thuggery? Prime Minister, who is next?

—The member who has just asked the question knows as well as I do that the members of the MUA have embarked upon a systematic campaign to send the company Patricks into bankruptcy and insolvency. They have embarked upon a systematic campaign, and anybody with eyes to see or ears to listen or a mind to comprehend will have seen a pattern of disruptive, negative, destructive conduct over the past few months. I have to say to the rank and file of the MUA that you have been badly let down by your union leadership. The union bosses of Australia have once again sold out the interest of the rank and file members of the trade union movement. But even worse than that is that the conspiracy along that destructive path between the leadership of the trade union movement and the Australian Labor Party has also sold out the interests of working men and women. Once again the men and women, the ordinary trade unionists of Australia—
—When the House is silent, I will call the member for Melbourne on a point of order.

—Thanks, Mr Speaker. Once again I asked a specific question about workers in Burnie and Darwin and Townsville and Port Kembla and Bell Bay and Mackay and various other places. The Prime Minister is not answering the question.
—The member for Melbourne has made his point of order. He will resume his seat. The Prime Minister is entirely relevant.

—There has been a clear pattern of conduct by the members of the MUA, orchestrated by the leadership of the union, inspired and encouraged at a political level by a Labor Party that cannot break itself free from the shackles of its trade union past. I have to say to those opposite that we are now living in the 1990s. We are living in an era in which the men and women of this country want decent, competitive, productive conditions. We are living in an era when our exporters want the opportunity to compete effectively against the rest of the world. We are living in an era when we want thousands more jobs created by having lively, competitive, productive industries. What is now occurring, this historic change which is now occurring on the Australian waterfront, is good news for future jobs in this country, it is good news for exports and it is good news for the international economic reputation of Australia. The only people for whom it is bad news are the union bosses who failed their members and the members of the Labor Party who are chained hand and foot to the union bosses of Australia.
—An unbelievably dignified performance that was.
—The Leader of the Opposition will stop his casual comments across the table. They are not appropriate.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. What effect will threats of industrial action against Australia by the International Transport Federation, operating out of London, have on the government's resolve to reform the waterfront in this country? What is the government's response to such industrial thuggery?

—The government will not put up with thuggery by industrial trade union leaders making threats from London against Australia. We will not put up with the threats of industrial thuggery from union leaders outside this country attempting to dictate to the duly elected government of the day. We have a legal team in place, the legal team has been in place in London now for some time, and we are in a position to see legal action taken both in Australia and internationally to counteract any attempt by the ITF to crystallise the threats that they have been making.

answer.para: I do understand the concerns of shipping companies in respect of the threats by the ITF. For that reason, I have had discussions with a number of shipping companies this morning on this issue. We have offered to those companies the legal advice that we have available to us and we put them in contact with the government's legal advisers. We have also made it very clear to those companies that, in conjunction with those companies, or separately or otherwise, we are prepared to take legal action if there is any crystallisation of those threats by the ITF against companies which are carrying on their lawful business in trading with Australia. I am pleased to say that a number of those companies that I have spoken to have contracts with Patrick, and I have been told this morning by shipping companies that they intend to continue their commercial relationship with Patrick, and they should know and understand that this government is absolutely determined to take this opportunity for reform. We will stick by those shipping companies to ensure that the reform opportunity for this country is grasped.

It is also worth noting that, whilst the ITF make threats about companies using both MUA and non-MUA labour in Australia, elsewhere around the world this is commonplace. People are so used to the monopoly of the MUA here that many do not appreciate that the idea of having MUA or non-MUA labour in Australia is what happens in virtually every other country around the world. That is why I think that, whilst we hear many threats coming from the ITF, ultimately it is unsustainable for them to pick out Australia and say that companies should not trade with Australia when those very same companies are going to ports in New Zealand and many other countries within the OECD where there is union or non-MUA labour. Lastly, I make this point: the shadow minister for transport asks, `What about some of the other ports; for example, Newcastle?' Newcastle is so bad that Patrick recently lost a contract.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: this is a matter of relevance. This was directed to an international matter but, if it is relevant to raise this, what about Tasmania where there has been an industrial exemption in place for decades where those unions have undertaken—
—The member will not argue his case; the member for Denison will resume his seat. The minister's answer is entirely relevant to the question asked.

—Just some facts. Newcastle is so bad that Patrick recently lost a contract to load 300,000 tonnes of aluminium for a Norwegian shipowner after the shipowner repeated complaints about the conduct of Patrick's workers over a two-year period. The fact is that standards in Australian ports are abysmally low, reliability is at appallingly low levels, and it is one reason why Australia has a shocking international reputation when it comes to the efficiency of our ports. This country has been made a laughing stock by these people running the MUA, supported by the ALP, who like the idea of having a few union bosses able to hold this country to ransom whenever it suits their political ends. I can assure the Leader of the Opposition those days are over.

—My question is to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Have the Victoria Police Association written to you expressing concern about the actions of the Office of Employment Advocate; in particular, about advice from the Employment Advocate that they would not be entitled to any pay for limited industrial action such as refusing to issue speeding tickets or to operate speed cameras? Are you aware that this advice has created the situation in which the police association are forced to consider industrial action which may include withdrawal of all police services in Victoria? Isn't this another example of your approach to industrial relations provoking escalation of industrial action?

—Isn't that interesting? We had four questions from them on the waterfront and now they are off onto an unrelated matter. This is the embarrassment that the Labor Party has had through this whole dispute. So embarrassed have you been, unable to publicly get out there and—

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order on relevance. He was asked a specif ic question about the application of his industrial act in relation to the police association in Victoria. He is now getting up and talking about anything but.
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his place. The minister will address the question put to him.

—I will do so with real pleasure, because section 187AA of the Workplace Relations Act, which the shadow minister refers to in his question, is one of the very many good things in the Workplace Relations Act. What that section says is that you will not be rewarded for taking industrial action. When this issue arose a couple of weeks ago in Sydney, the Labor Party condemned the provisions of the act, but when I put out a press release noting the fact that it was the same law in New South Wales which had been supported by the Labor Party in New South Wales all of a sudden they went quiet. When it comes to the level of industrial disputes, one of the reasons we have on the Australian waterfront nine times the national average is that, under Labor, if you took industrial action, you could be rewarded for taking that action, and we have placed a ban on people being rewarded for taking industrial action. What happened in Sydney is also very revealing—it shows you the strength of these provisions—because when this matter first came to a head the wharfies said, `Oh well, we'll take'—

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I asked a question with regard to the Police Association of Victoria, which has not been referred to yet. In all the time that the minister has been responding, he has not referred to that matter at all.
—The minister needs to respond to the question put to him.
—Yes, I will. The proposition being put to me is that there is a threat of industrial action because of section 187AA.
—Have you got the letter?
—I do not know if I have the letter or not. I have not read it.
—I will give you a copy.
—Table it.
—Yes, you can send it around to me, thanks very much. As a postie, you might do better.

answer.para: The point I am making is that, when the wharfies went back to work after their first seven-day strike, did they continue with their overtime ban? No, they did not. And why didn't they? Because they wanted to be paid. They wanted to be paid—and section 187AA was very effective indeed.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, my point of order goes to relevance. This is completely absurd. He has not yet mentioned, in about a four-minute answer, one word about the Police Association. He says that he does not know about it, so he ought to sit down.
—The question was framed with a narrow bar, but it also had a broad context. The minister is in response and he is quite relevant in that general context.

—To conclude my answer, the point I am making—which is a difficult point for the Labor Party to understand—is that there are a lot of unions that will make threats of industrial action. But what you need to have in place is effective laws. And 187AA has shown to be a very effective discouragement for those unions wanting to take industrial action—very effective in dealing with the wharfies, and just as effective in dealing with anybody else who wants to take industrial action. Under our laws, they will not be rewarded for doing so.
—I seek leave to table a letter from the Police Association to the minister, dated 2 April.

interjection.para: Leave not granted.

talk.start.para: —I would like to extend, on behalf of all members, a warm welcome to a delegation from the National Council of Provinces of the Republic of South Africa, led by the Chairperson of the NCAP, Mr Patrick Lekota. Welcome to Australia.
—Hear, hear!
—My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade. Minister, can you outline to the House the significance of waterfront reform to Australian exporters?
—I thank the member for Hinkler for his question.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —We have a pathetic noisy opposition here today. Where were the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition last night when they should have been at the dispatch box, answering for their own good? Where were you? We know where you were at lunchtime today; you were launching a book of some kind or another.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The Deputy Prime Minster will return to answering the question.
—Mr Speaker—

—Mr Speaker, my point of order goes to relevance. The Deputy Prime Minister wrote this dorothy dixer; he ought to at least be able to keep on track with it. I would ask you to tell him to come to order.
—The Deputy Prime Minister will answer the question.
—As a matter of fact, I did not write this particular dorothy dixer, but I am very happy to answer it.

answer.para: Mr Bevis interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Brisbane.

—We know what annoys you. What really annoys you is that several hundred thousand workers voted for the coalition at the last election, many of them trade unionists. Indeed, they will do it again—and we will give them good and proper reason to do it again. We even have a trade unionist sitting in the coalition ranks: the member for Capricornia, a shop steward and proud of it—and on the coalition side. We have a task to do here.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The Deputy Prime Minister will answer the question put to him. Could I have a little silence in the House before I again call the Deputy Prime Minister?

—Mr Speaker, I accept your guidance. I think we should look at some comparative costings with regard to the movement of containers. Let us look at the loading of timber logs, as one particular example. In Australia it costs $5.60 a tonne, with a nine-day ship turnaround. Compare that with New Zealand at $2.20 a tonne, with a four-day ship turnaround. So, if you just take that one example with regard to the timber industry, the Australian cost structure is more than twice that of New Zealand.

answer.para: But take the crane rates. I welcome the South African delegation in the gallery. I know that they are trying to open up the Maputo Corridor and the Mozambique outlets. I congratulate them on that because, in fact, the Port of Mozambique is performing at a better crane rate—25 containers an hour—than the average of the ports of Australia.

We have a huge task ahead to get it right on the waterfront. That we seek to do that is in the interests of the workers of Australia, the standard of living of the workers of Australia and the export performance of Australia. Professor Blainey wrote many years ago that Australia suffers from a tyranny of distance. Our exporters are particularly challenged by the fact that they are deep in the Southern Hemisphere and a lot of our competitors are in the Northern Hemisphere. The very least we can provide for them is best international practice, with regard to micro-economic reform and the waterfront.
So let us give our job creating exporters a fair go. Let us give our export containers efficient cost-reduced passage through our ports—and the sooner, the better, for the sake of all Australians.

talk.start.para: —Will the Treasurer confirm that the `other than incidental' clause in the government's proposed new tax treatment of franking credits—

—Could the members of the frontbench of the opposition remain silent so that we can the question? Could I ask the honourable member to ask his question again? I have not been able to hear it. Could you ask the question again?

—Certainly. Mr Speaker, will the Treasurer confirm that the `other than incidental' clause in the government's proposed new tax treatment of franking credits will trigger part 4A of the 1936 Income Tax Assessment Act when the stakeholders in Telstra sell their shares, following the conversion of those shares to ordinary shares? What action will the government take to ensure that those many Australians who own Telstra shares, but who may not be aware that they will be exposed to the new anti-avoidance provisions when they divest themselves of shares, are made aware of this new proposal?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. The measures which were announced in the 1997 budget relating to dividend streaming were designed to ensure that a party would not be entitled to take the benefit of imputation credits unless they bore some of the risk. One of the measures that was put in place to ensure that you bore some of the risk was a requirement that you hold for 45 days or, alternatively to that, part 4A was amended to apply to such transactions.

answer.para: Part 4A in its application to the rules in relation to dividend streaming says that it can be struck down by part 4A in the event that one of its purposes was to get the advantage and that was other than an incidental purpose. The test is an objective test which would require the courts to look at all of the conduct.

Those people who were holding the shares as part of either a strategy of increasing the capital value of the share as part of hedging or who had a normative purpose—including the millions of mothers and fathers in Australia who had bought them—would not I expect be caught by that test in any sense at all, because they would only be caught if it could be shown that they had come in to take advantage of dividend streaming and were not interested in a proper investment either for other purposes such as capital increase, or for other purposes such as hedging.

In those circumstances I believe that there is no real risk under the amendments to part 4A to those millions of Australians who have invested in the Telstra shares. Certainly, it is not the objective of the changes to part 4A to bring them into that net. I can give them and the member for Curtin an assurance that the application of the law will not affect the holding of what I consider to be a very good investment.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Will the minister please inform the House how the state of Australia's waterfront efficiency affects Australia's image within the region as a reliable international trading partner?

—I thank the member for Fisher for his question and recognise his concern for Australia being successful in the so-called globalised economy. Globalisation is a theme of the member for Werriwa's well-known book which was launched today by the Leader of the Opposition.

answer.para: There is no doubt that Australia's notorious reputation for an inefficient waterfront is internationally known and understood, and is an international embarrassment for Australia. Quite frankly, our waterfront performance is a standing joke in countries such as New Zealand and China. If anybody ever wanted any evidence for this proposition, they only have to look at the Far Eastern Economic Review editorial of 19 February 1998.

talk.start.para: —What about all the editorials on Parer?
—It may be well worth the opposition listening to this, because this is a reference to the opposition as well as it is to Australia as a whole. The editorial states:

answer.para: In the past few years Australian officials have been fond of talking of Australia joining Asia.
That proposition by the Far Eastern Economic Review is indeed very true. But the editorial went on to say:
It is becoming more clear that this might first depend on having their dock workers become part of the 20th century.
The article went on to say:
Certainly the MUA appears to come from a different era.
Mr Speaker, if you ever wanted to know what the world thinks of Australia's waterfront, then that illustration from the Far Eastern Economic Review is a very good one.

The House would be well aware that the comparisons between Australian ports and ports around our region and the world are most unflattering. A recent international comparison showed that the port of Laem Chabang in Thailand turns around about 30 containers an hour; Hong Kong, 25 to 30; Singapore, 25 to 30; Auckland, 25; and by comparison Sydney can only manage 18 containers an hour and Melbourne 18½ containers an hour. I would have thought that any self-respecting member of this parliament would be very concerned about that, would want to see that productivity improve and not try to defend the status quo.

In a recent survey of 18 international ports Sydney was ranked last, that is 18th, in reliability, 18th in turnaround speed and 17th out of 18 in terms of value for money. I am sorry to have to concede the point that my own home town's Port of Adelaide was rated 18th out of 18 in terms of worst value for money.

There may be some people in the Labor Party who regard that as acceptable. They spent 13 years in government. They talked about waterfront reform, but they did not do it. Our record is still a bad record and it is embarrassing to our international reputation.

I will come back to what is admittedly one of the smaller incidents of the day, the launch of the member for Werriwa's book. How nice of him to turn up just as I mentioned his book. Having finished answering questions at the press club, he now turns up to the parliament. I think it is probably what Laurie Oakes meant when he talked about you being absent without leave.

The member for Werriwa talks in his book about globalisation. What he says about globalisation is absolutely right. It is all about trying to bring the Labor Party into the latter part of the 20th century. One of the points he makes in his book which is worth reflecting on is this:
This is not the time or place for the preservation of sacred cows.

He may be alone on that side of the House in holding that view, but at least he understands the point about globalisation, international efficiency and modernising Australia, even if the dinosaurs here have no understanding at all.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Does the Treasurer agree that, unless banking, insurance and similar financial services are not merely exempt from GST, as is usual elsewhere, but also zero rated, substantial additional costs will still have to be passed onto consumers if the banks and insurance companies are to cover the costs of GST paid on their inputs? Will you commit the government to zero rating GST in its application to banking, insurance and financial services?
—The honourable member for Isaacs will remain silent.

interjection.para: Mr Wilton interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I warn the member for Isaacs!

—The member for Isaacs is one of the great intellectuals of the Labor Party. We would like to encourage more interjections from him. I have already indicated what the government's view is on these little trick questions. We will announce our tax policy at a time that suits us, and we will not be announcing it in question time on a Wednesday afternoon, thank you very much. I am rather amazed that the Australian Labor Party stands so squarely against tax reform and modernised tax—
—But not yours.

—Oh, no; they are in favour of tax reform, they are just against every proposal which would accomplish it. That is their position: `We're in favour of tax reform, we just oppose any changes to the current system.' What a fraudulent position that is.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I thought `fraud' was out.
—I did not say `fraud',
—Oh, so `fraudulent' is in, Mr Speaker?
—The member for Hotham will resume his seat. If he wishes to raise a point of order, he will do so properly. I did not hear the word `fraud'.
—What? You didn't.
—If the honourable member will remain silent, you have raised your point of order. I am currently addressing the response to the Treasurer.
—But, Mr Speaker—
—Resume your seat. The Treasurer, if he used the word `fraud' with respect to an individual in the opposition, I suggest will withdraw it.
—I did not use the word `fraud', Mr Speaker.
—Oh!
—You said `fraudulent'.
—I did not use the word `fraud'. Let me talk about a modern taxation system.
—Mr Speaker, on the point of order. My point to you was his use of `fraudulent' not `fraud'.
—You did not—
—I am asking you whether `fraud' is out and `fraudulent' is in. We want the list so we know the consistency.
—The member for Hotham will resume his seat if he wants to stay in this place. You may ask properly if words to which you take offence and have been used against you should be withdrawn.
—On a point of order—

—I am responding, if the member for Brisbane has two seconds to spare. As far as the Treasurer is concerned, he has said he did not use the word `fraud'. I gather now you say that he said you were fraudulent. Is that correct?
—Which is what I said in the first place.
—Did the Treasurer say you were fraudulent?
—I said it was a fraudulent position to say you are in favour of tax reform and to oppose all measures which would change the current system.
—That is entirely within the standing orders.
—And properly within the standing orders.
—The Treasurer therefore can continue his remarks.

—The Australian Labor Party opposes broad based indirect tax. That is the one thing we know about. It opposes broad based indirect tax, and it supports the wholesale sales tax. Which countries have a wholesale sales tax?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order on relevance. The Treasurer was asked a specific question about GST—no ambit claims in relation to it; a specific question about banking and financial services. It was narrowly cast. Now he has answered it by saying he will not answer it, and now he is going to argue a general proposition.
—The question was framed in a context of tax reform.

—I was asked a question about broad based indirect tax, and I am going to make this point. The following countries seem to be able to manage it: Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Indonesia, Ireland, Israel.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order going to relevance. There is nothing in his crummy little red pamphlet that says a word about financial or banking services. That was the question; why don't you answer it? Why do you continue to hide your intentions—
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The Treasurer has the call. The Treasurer is entirely relevant in his answer.

—The following countries in the world seem to be able to manage broad based indirect tax in its application: Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, Mexico, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Philippines, Russia, Singapore, South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Thailand and the United Kingdom. The following countries support the Labor Party's wholesale sales tax: Botswana, Ghana, Jordan, Pakistan, the Solomon Islands and Swaziland.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel. Minister, are you aware of repeated approaches that have been made to your office, going back to August of 1996, from Lt Col. Harry Smith, retired, who was the officer who commanded D Company 6 RAR at the Battle of Long Tan on 18 August 1966? Why have you not investigated Colonel Smith's allegations that his recommendations for Military Cross awards for two of his platoon commanders in that battle were destroyed and that they were given a lesser award, one that was also handed out to the postal clerk at Vung Tau? Why did you refuse to investigate these matters before closing the End of War List for the Vietnam War, and will you now give the House an undertaking that these issues will be fully investigated and that the Australian soldiers who clearly displayed gallant and distinguished service in action at the Battle of Long Tan will be properly recognised?
—The member for Brisbane should be aware, before I call the minister, that particular questions of that sort are normally asked to be put on notice.

—I would say that, in all the matters that are brought to my attention that require investigation, I am punctilious in carrying out that investigation. I would take your advice, Mr Speaker, and ask that the question be placed on notice. I would be pleased to come back with a fulsome answer. I note that, in all the years that they were in government—13 years—there was absolutely nothing done about the End of War List at all. We have had the good grace to fulfil our promise and announce that list. I simply will not tolerate the sort of nonsense that comes out of the opposition in trying to pretend that they are now concerned when they obviously were not for 13 years.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order on relevance. She was asked a specific question about this action. They did nothing about the end of war lists for seven years in government—
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. There is no point of order.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, could you please inform the House of the importance of waterfront reform to all the farmers of Australia, including those in the Riverina?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I must say at the outset that it is interesting that with all those champions of the bush over there who run around saying that they are the answer to all the problems of the bush, they have not asked a question in relation to waterfront reform and its importance to the rural sector. Where are the member for Burke and the member for Hunter, let alone the cockies' friend, the member for Hotham?

answer.para: There are about 120,000 farmers in Australia and about 20,000 of them could provide enough food and fibre to look after all Australians' needs. The other 100,000 rely upon exports for their livelihoods and so do hundreds of thousands of people in the processing sectors, the value adding sectors that spring from agriculture. They are amongst the world's most efficient, by anybody's standards—and we are all very proud of them. But those first-world performers in those industries are outrageously held back by third-world performance on the waterfront. That is what happens. Farmers face international competition and, to win, they would like a waterfront sector that helps them win, not hinders them.

We recently had a National Farmers Federation study which showed that a 25 per cent fall in the cost of shifting goods—and it needs to be remembered that we have about double the costs of our competitors—across the Australian waterfront would improve the prices of rural produce in Australia by one per cent. That, in turn, would improve farm business profit by 27 per cent.

Our multibillion dollar meat exports, for example, are containerised. Millions could be saved and put back into the pockets of farmers if we could get decent waterfront reform. Our dairy industry alone provides 100,000 jobs. We know about these champions of the workers over there. With these hundreds of thousands of jobs built on exports—we have 36 per cent of Asia's dairy market—we are involved in a fight to the death with our competitors from countries like New Zealand and America where they are reforming and continuing to cut costs on their waterfronts.

You have heard the Deputy Prime Minister talk about the fact that it costs vastly more to move timber across our ports than it does in America's ports. I have been asked by citrus importers in Indonesia why it is—and this is very interesting—that it takes nine days for them to import citrus from America and 16 days to import citrus from Australia. And that is in an industry we would like to see succeed on export markets. Apparently, you do not and neither do your mates in the MUA.

What is the attitude of our waterfront mates in relation to this? A few modest reforms from these highly privileged elitists could improve farmers' incomes dramatically. How do they respond? I will tell you, Mr Speaker, how they respond: they claim that they are better than they used to be. They refer to history in this country. But that is utterly irrelevant for a trading nation like Australia. Historical comparisons about where they were five, six, seven or eight years ago are utterly irrelevant. What matters is how we stack up against our competitors. We are an exporting country. That is where our jobs and our prosperity lie and where our future must be secured. We are about securing those jobs, those living standards and that future; you and your mates plainly are about exporting them.

talk.start.para: —To restore the balance, as I called two Opposition members consecutively, I now call the honourable member for Corangamite.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, would you advise the House whether there have been any statements by the ACTU about developments on the waterfront, and what is the government's response to these statements?

—I thank the member for Corangamite for his question. The President of the ACTU has made some remarks this morning. What I think is interesting is that we have yet to hear from the Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Kelty. Mr Kelty is basically the one who runs the ACTU. These others are just the fronts for the ACTU but the remarks by the President of the ACTU this morning portrayed their concern about breaching the Trade Practices Act—and they are right to be concerned about the penalties which people can be subject to for breaches of the Trade Practices Act. What she said is, `We will have a response, but it will be muted; it will be united; and our first priority must be the workers, their families and their children.'

answer.para: The redundancy program which the government announced this morning will ensure that those workers who are made redundant will receive their full entitlements, including superannuation, which can be up to $270,000. Those are very generous redundancy arrangements by any community standard. I heard John Coombs saying this morning that these were miserable payments—over a quarter of a million dollars. Only the head of the wharfies' union could make such a claim.

We will ensure that these redundancy entitlements are paid. I make the point that this is an industry wide scheme and these funds will be available for any workers made redundant, whether it be in the associated labour hire companies, those labour hire companies which have had contracts with Patrick's or any employees in any other stevedoring organisations.

One of the significant aspects of the developments that we have is the commitment by P&O to the benchmark performance targets set by the government. We expect those objectives to be achieved within a 12- to 18-month time frame. The figures are interesting. I understand that, roughly, the labour force available to Patrick until now has comprised around 1,400 people. But the number of people who will be working under contracts to provide the same services will be in the order of 400 or 500—a very significant reduction, which shows you the extent of overmanning in the industry. With efficient operations, this industry can be run not only more productively and more reliably but also generally at a lower cost for the users of stevedore services.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, didn't the member for Casey resign as Speaker because, despite your promise of an independent Speaker, you broke your word? Didn't the member for Lowe resign because he grew sick and tired of your broken promises, saying that your promises are not worth the paper they are written on? Hasn't the member for McPherson resigned because he disagreed with your government's stance on nursing homes, Wik and the stolen generation, amongst other issues?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Each of the propositions advanced by the Leader of the Opposition relies on an attribution of motive to a member on this side, and each of them is beyond the limit of ministerial responsibility under standing order 142. I ask you to rule the question out of order.

—The Prime Minister is responsible for ministerial arrangements within this place. While the question implies motives, the Prime Minister is responsible for the appointment of ministers. Consequently, the question at this stage is still in order.

—How many more of your colleagues are going to jump ship? Prime Minister, how many more resignations will it take before you finally get the message that many Australians, including a growing number of your own supporters, find you a divisive, confrontational Prime Minister and have lost faith in you?
—The Leader of the Opposition needs to be very careful.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The question clearly has inferences and I ask you to rule it out of order.

—I have considered the question carefully. There is within standing order 144 a number of restraints which the Leader of the Opposition went very carefully around. I am afraid that, while there were areas that I thought may have been questionable, I think the overall purport of the question is clear and within the Prime Minister's responsibility. I therefore call on the Prime Minister.

—I of course reject the basis of the question that has been asked by the Leader of the Opposition. But, because he has raised the subject of general political attitudes in Australia, it gives me an opportunity to say a few things. The first remark I make is that they left the waterfront by 2.35 this afternoon. They walked off. The waterfront gave themselves a rostered day off at 2.35 this afternoon. I remember reading some of the columns before the parliament resumed. We had all of these columns about how they could not wait to get us back to ask us about Dubai. Were they going to ask us difficult questions about Dubai. Were they really going to put my colleague the minister for workplace relations in the dock on Dubai.

answer.para: Of course, the reality is that they are petrified to pursue the issue of reform on the waterfront. The reason they are petrified to pursue it is that the ordinary men and women of Australia back us on the waterfront. The ordinary men and women of Australia know that the waterfront has been rorted for years. The ordinary men and women of Australia are fed up with the abusive tactics of the trade union bosses. The ordinary men and women of Australia know that the Leader of the Opposition is bound hand and foot to John Coombs on this issue.

As for the Leader of the Opposition talking about division and standards, the Leader of the Opposition does not have the courage to pursue somebody himself. He gets his muck-raker in the Senate, Robert Ray, to trawl through the sewers. He does not have the guts to discipline the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He has been prepared to allow the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to invoke and incite racial hatred in this community. He has been unwilling to control that motormouth, the apology for a Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who sits behind him. I think the Australian community see the Leader of the Opposition as a weak, wimpish, lap-dog of the trade union movement.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. We do not believe in the nick on this side of the House. Minister, would you please advise the House whether any taxpayers' funds will be used in reforming the waterfront?

—I thank the member for Moreton for his question. The government will be putting in place a scheme where the cost will be borne by industry. This is an interesting contrast to the program introduced by the Labor Party in 1989-92, where a big slice of the funds last time were shelled out by the Labor Party shelling out taxpayers' funds. To add insult to injury, they never got the change in performance, the improved productivity, which was the whole purpose of the exercise in the first place. This scheme being put in place by the government will be at no cost to the taxpayer. Furthermore, the cost of this exercise will be absorbed by the stevedoring companies themselves.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The same minister introduced legislation—
—The member will raise his point of order.
—Yes, I am raising my point of order. He raised the question of the legislation today. He is now dealing with the issues under that legislation.

—As the honourable member for Calwell knows, technically the legislation is not yet on the Notice Paper . But you are right; it has been moved through its first reading to the second reading, and debate has commenced. Provided the minister does not refer specifically to the details within the bill, this sort of answer has traditionally been allowed within our standing orders.

—I am happy to conclude my answer, because I wanted to make this final point: today has been very revealing. During question time, have there been nine or 10 questions from the opposition on this issue? No, there has not. Why hasn't there? Because they do not have the guts to stand up for the national interest. These people have never had a policy on this issue other than to do what they have been told by the MUA leadership and the ACTU.

debateinfo.title: SUSPENSION OF STANDING AND SESSSIONAL ORDERS

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business moving forthwith at the completion of this suspension motion and without debate: `that this House supports the introduction of genuine competition on the waterfront and the right of all employees to join or not to join a union of their choice and the outcomes which will flow from a more efficient, reliable waterfront, including:
(1) creating more exports to help reduce Australia's foreign debt and improve job opportunities for the Australian people;
(2) creating more jobs in manufacturing;
(3) improving the opportunity of small businesses to grow and develop in world markets;
(4) improving the safety of all workplaces on the waterfront; and
(5) fuelling economic growth which will lead to higher living standards for all Australians.'
The fact of the matter is that we said that we would fix the waterfront and we meant it. For years and years this running sore on the waterfront—

talk.start.para: —So what are we doing now?

—I am moving my motion. You will have your chance when you have understood what I have done. You will have your chance to see whether or not you are prepared to stand in this parliament and vote for genuine reform of the Australian waterfront. All the rhetoric, all the muck-raking—that has all come to an end.

speech.para: Mr Bob Baldwin interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The member for Paterson is not in his place.

—This afternoon, after I have moved successfully this suspension motion, those opposite will have not a chance to filibuster, not a chance to give us political rhetoric; they will have a simple chance, a simple choice, and that is to indicate to the Australian community whether or not they genuinely support reform of the waterfront or not. They have talked about it. They have fed out the misinformation from the MUA, but today is their opportunity—

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The point of order is this: the gentleman is calling for a debate on this issue, but he has moved a motion which says `at the completion of this suspension motion and without debate'. Is it legitimate to move a suspension of standing orders to consider a motion that the parliament then cannot debate. Is it appropriate to move a motion that we cannot debate a particular proposition?

—The contents of any motion, so long as they fall within the standing orders, must be heard by this place. It has been moved. We are talking about suspension of standing orders for that purpose. The terms of the motion are not within the chair's—

interjection.para: Mr Beazley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Does the Leader of the Opposition wish to pursue the matter? I suggest he remain silent. I call the Leader of the House, who is moving his motion.

—The Leader of the Opposition had half an hour this morning, and what we are saying to him this afternoon is those opposite have to come in here and either vote for reform or vote against it. I do not think there is any doubt about what they will do: they will vote against it because the MUA require that of them.

speech.para: Mr Bob Baldwin interjecting—

talk.start.para: —And what an embarrassment for the Labor Party. It was only back in January when the union leadership—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I may be wrong, because it may be the government's rotational seat—
—What is your point of order?
—but I do believe the member for Paterson is out of his place and he continues to interject. I ask you to call him to order.

—If the member for Paterson has been interjecting—and, frankly, there was so much noise I did not hear him—I have already identified to the honourable member he is out of his place. He either resumes his place if he wishes to intervene or remain silent.

—This is a simple choice for the Labor Party: either they support reform or they do not; either they support the right of people to join or not join a union of their choice or they do not. We will simply put those propositions to this House. I can assure members that we on this side of the House are unequivocally, unambiguously in favour of waterfront reform.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—No matter how many disruptive points of order there are, we intend that motion to be put.
—Although the motion says that it should be considered without debate, will that mean that if we seek to move an amendment to the—
—That is not a point of order.
—No, it is. Please, Mr Speaker—
—Please put it. You have not raised a point of order yet.
—Will it mean that, if an amendment is moved to the motion, it cannot be debated either, or will you allow that to be debated?
—You can raise that at the appropriate time. That is not a point of order in the middle of the member's—
—Yes, it is. It is about this motion.
—It is not—not to the motion while it is being moved. You can move it at the appropriate time.

—What we have seen in this parliament in the last week is a Labor Party that have no policy positions—no position on, for example, the fact that small business interest rates have fallen, no position on the great issues of the day facing the country, such as waterfront reform, except to mouth that which has been put to them by the trade union movement and the MUA. Their response has therefore been to run a campaign of smear and gutter politics in substitute for genuine policy positions. It is therefore no surprise that we should see in the Bulletin this morning that Laurie Oakes's latest writings on politics say:

speech.para: Kim Beazley is failing to display strong leadership, and key people are letting him down.

If ever there was a classic case of the failure of the Labor Party and the failure of the Leader of the Opposition to provide some leadership, it is on this issue of the waterfront and the need for reform. This morning the Leader of the Opposition made an incredible claim in the parliament and I understand also on radio that the levels of productivity in Australia had significantly improved and that basically we did not have a problem. He said that we had crane rates of 24 and 25.

I have here the latest publication from the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics, which has a March 1998 issue date—it came out at only the end of March—and it mentions the five port average crane rates in Australia. For the major container terminals where the vast bulk of the containers go through, this is the performance indicator: in December 1996, 17.1; in March 1997, 18.4; in June 1997, 18.3; in September 1997, 18.3; and, in 1997, 18.5. And he is out there claiming 24 and 25. These are the official figures; they are a national disgrace.

I sat down with John Coombs at the end of 1996 and I said to him, `John, Australia cannot go on having a rate of productivity, a lack of reliability on the Australian waterfront, which puts us behind the rest of the international community.' I sat and spoke with him about the need to improve produc tivity on the waterfront. And what was his answer? His answer was, `Don't be provocative.' When you say to John Coombs, `Why does the Australian waterfront have a level of strike action nine times the national average?' what does he say? He says, `Don't be provocative.' When you say to him, `John, there are a whole lot of blokes in Melbourne who drive cranes and who get paid $90,000 a year and, on average, work only 14 hours a week,' what does he say? He says, `Don't be provocative.' When you say to him, `John, why can't we do as well as Manila where they do 30 crane lifts an hour? Why can't we do as well as New Zealand where they do 25? Why can't we do as well as Laem Chabang outside Bangkok? Why can't we do as well as Mozambique?' what does he say? He says, `Don't be provocative.' Who is the little echo who supports him? It is none other than the Leader of the Opposition.

When you say to John Coombs, `Look at Australia compared to international ports,' he says, `You can't make international comparisons.' So what have we done? We have produced figures which show that the levels of productivity vary greatly in the one port, on the same ship, on the same day. Why do they vary greatly? In the afternoon, you are on ordinary time; in the evening, you are on double time and a half. But the deal on the Australian waterfront is that, when you finish the job, you get to go home and you still get paid for the whole of the shift. So, if the shift requires a couple of hours work but it is a 7½-hour shift, you get paid for the 7½ hours even though for five of them you are sitting at home watching Wednesday night at the movies—all paid for by exporters, by Australian jobs, by Australian businesses trying to compete.

This situation has gone on for years and years. The Labor Party turned a blind eye to it. They forked out $430 million—$173 million of taxpayers' money—and now they say, `Our answer to this problem is that we'll bring back Bob Hawke. We will have a meeting to discuss it.' What do they want to do today? They want more discussion about this.

This country has had a gutful of discussion; it is time the waterfront was fixed up. Your January resolution supported genuine competition on the waterfront. Today, when this motion is carried, you have got a simple choice: you either stand up for reform, show some leadership for a change or you deny reform and tie yourself hand and foot to the MUA as you have been all along. I commend the motion to the House. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The answer to the member for Canberra's point of order is that a motion for the suspension of standing orders can be amended but will require a seconder.

—The mask is now off, after months of deceit, months of lies, months of evasions, about what this government is on about. What we have got is the media tested market strategy for taxpayer funded consultancies that have set the groundwork, first, through Dubai and then the National Farmers Federation—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I am keen to listen to the member for Melbourne's speech, but the clock has not started to time it.
—Will the member for Cowan resume his place. The clock ticks on anyway in a motion for the suspension of standing orders.

—Some mothers do have `em. First, we had Dubai, then the National Farmers Federation training replacement workers and now the true story is coming clear, the true story is coming plain: it is about sacking 1,400 existing workers of Patrick. We have got the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Mr Reith, the member for Flinders, who has pronounced all of these workers en masse to be unproductive, to be worthy of the sack, to be worthy of vilification. He has whipped up public hatred and contempt. He has engaged in a vicious campaign of calumny and vilification against these workers for months and months, full of outrageous lies, abuse and stories that have no basis in fact: the wharfies in Fremantle are supposedly knocking off early to go to a strip show—based on one jocular remark from one person leaving work, joking, saying that they were going to a strip show. Some how, the vilification of wharfies in 1942—most of whom, presumably, are long dead—is a basis for sacking existing wharfies. This is the sort of outrageous stuff that this minister has been going on about.

speech.para: What we saw last night is the stuff of military dictatorships: in the middle of the night, 1,400 people dismissed without warning, without any reference to their performance, their individual activity. The knock on the door; they are told, `Sorry, you're gone.' What they take with them is Reith's reference. On top of their dismissal, they have got months of calumny, months of vilification that tells the whole world, every prospective employer for these, mostly, 40- to 45-year-old men: do not employ these people. So not only are they sacked but they are also put in a position where it would be extremely hard for them to ever get work again—all courtesy of this minister, who is putting his hand on the taxpayers of Australia to fund all of this.

This is where the fundamental injustice of this lies: here we have the Liberal Party of Australia, the great party of the individual, the great party of Menzies that stands up for the individual—and have those 1,400 individuals got any chance at all to defend their performance as an individual worker? Answer: no. They are being treated en bloc, en masse, and are being told by this government, `You are all sacked.' They have no chance at all to defend themselves as individuals, no chance to say, `Here is my performance in Townsville, in Burnie, in Bell Bay, in Mackay or wherever.'

These are not redundancies because work is continuing; the job is still there. To call it a redundancy is false. These workers are being replaced. As this opposition said from day one: they are being replaced by the NFF, which was not a competitor on the waterfront; it was a training operation for the very purpose for which it is now being used. No doubt we will see this tested in unfair dismissal proceedings. We now know why Peter Reith, the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, wants to abolish the unfair dismissal laws: so that he can sack people holus bolus with no threat of retribution.

These redundancies are being funded by a new tax—another breach of a promise, just by the by—while Patricks asset strips. So this government are not only supporting Chris Corrigan's action in sacking all of these workers, they are paying him to do it. They are saying, `We will give you the money. We will tax the taxpayers of Australia—the port users of Australia and the end consumers of Australia—and we will pay you to sack these people not as individuals but as a group.'

If you look at it, there are 17 ports where Patricks workers have been sacked, many of them at world's best practice in spite of the nonsense that he carries on about. At many of them there have been no strikes for years. Townsville, for example, has throughput that has quadrupled within five or six years. I challenge the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to go to Townsville, to Mackay, to Burnie and to all the other places and look those workers in the eye and tell them why they have been sacked by this government through taxpayer funded arrangements, why this government says they are engaged in industrial thuggery and why this government says they are unproductive.

All of them have been sacked. They were all waking up this morning wondering what they were going to do about their mortgage, wondering what they were going to tell their spouse and their children, and wondering where they were going to get another job. This is a nasty, vicious government—a malevolent government—and the mask is finally off. The plan all the way along in this exercise has been to sack 1,400 people arbitrarily with no individual consideration of their performance. It is a bring back the dog-collar act: bring back the individual contracts and bring back the master and servant relationship. That is what they believe; that is what they are on about. The mask is now off.

There are a lot of workers in this country who are now treading very nervously as a result of the events of last night. Who is next? Who is going to have the government's eye turned to it next and be told, `You are not productive enough. You are a rorter. You are going to get the axe because we say that you are a rorter.' People are asking themselves, `How can I collectively bargain? How can I deal with my employer, a large organisation with a lot of money? How can I, as an individual, collectively bargain under this government?' They are asking themselves, `Can I afford to abandon my insurance? Can I afford to say: yes, unfair dismissal legislation, we do not need that, that is fine?' They are asking themselves, `How is it that somebody who works in a world's best practice port that has not been on strike for years can be sacked, in effect by this government paying our employer to sack us, for no other reason than that we are members of the Maritime Union of Australia?'

Who is next? Construction workers? Flight attendants? Teachers? Train drivers? Everybody is entitled to worry. The rule book has just been thrown out by this government. It is the action of a military dictatorship, not a democratically elected government in a society like Australia. This government says it supports competition, yet in Dampier it supports a monopoly: it supports P&O being thrown out by the state government.

And it talks about rorts. We are getting one a week from this government. First we had Senator Woods, then the member for Hume (Mr Sharp) and now there are a couple of unnamed members in sight after the last couple of days. Where is that going to head? These are the great moralists of Australian politics who preached to Australian workers about rorts. There was the man who invented the nick—the man who perfected the nick and who used to lecture waterfront workers. Because he perfected the nick and got caught we now have the honourable member for Flinders as the new minister. He is only there because of what happened to his predecessor.

Minister, these are people. These are human beings. These are ordinary workers. You have orchestrated their dismissal for no valid reason with regard to individual performance. This action is already provoking strikes. It is already provoking bitter confrontation, resulting in extra costs for Australian exporters. At the same time that you can find tax money to pay for sacking wharfies you cannot do the same to pay for nursing home funding. You cannot do the same for Australian hospitals but it is okay to breach a promise about taxation in order to sack wharfies. That gives you a really good indication of what this government is really about.

This is the outrageous act of a vicious, malignant government. It is the act of a man—the human oil slick—who is chasing hard right-wing votes in a leadership contest and who has to show, at the cost of the jobs and the long-term futures of 1,400 workers and their families, what a hairy chest he has got. He is hurting many innocent people, throwing 1,400 workers onto the street in positions where they may not be able to pay their mortgages. They may lose their houses. Undoubtedly some marriages will break down as a result of this. He is provoking industrial conflict and imposing a new tax on Australian exporters.
Irrespective of debates about productivity and regardless of what your view is—and there are numerous views about the productivity of the Australian waterfront—this is not the way.

talk.start.para: —What's your view?

—My view is that you tell a lot of falsehoods in this debate. This is not the way that you deal with these issues in Australia. The right to some job security and the right to bargain collectively in this country are now in tatters as a result of this government's actions. Who is next? Is every Australian worker whom the government deems to be insufficiently productive now susceptible to being sacked arbitrarily? I move:

speech.para: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "this House deplores the action of the Government in organising the financing of the dismissal of 1,400 Australian workers in breach of the Workplace Relations Act and the relevant award provisions".
This government is sowing the wind and by God it will reap the whirlwind on this issue.

talk.start.para: —I second the amendment. The government has acted with maximum mendacity on this matter. Over the last 12 months the public of Australia have seen this government walk around saying that they have no involvement with the conspiracy to sack the waterfront work force. They and the employer in this case have gone around uttering assurances. As far as that is concerned, all is revealed today: they were all part of a pattern of government misleading of the Australian population, and all part now of an attack on the security of the Australian work force. Understand this: as far as the workers here are concerned they have been targeted for one reason only—not because they rort, not because they are disruptive, not because they are somehow un-Australian but because they are members of a union.

speech.para: In question time we drew attention to this fact. Workers in areas which have never in recent memory had anything like an industrial dispute are also under the gun and have been fired. Workers who have produced what was in the speech of the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) to his legislation acknowledged as world best practice in the movement of bulk cargoes have been sacked. Workers in Townsville who have quadrupled productivity over the course of the last six years and who have contributed to that world best practice have been sacked. Workers in ports such as Burnie and other Tasmanian ports where there has not been industrial disputes in living memory have been sacked. And we have a callous Prime Minister (Mr Howard) standing up here saying, `Well, they deserve it.'

They are Australians who have been productive; Australians who have families—families nowhere near as well off as those on the frontbench opposite, who have been scurrying away from the consequences of one of the greatest rorts of all time in the taxation system in this country, collapsing standards in this place of reportability and accountability. Those opposite are grand-scale rorters standing in judgment of ordinary Australians doing the things that ordinary Australians do—ordinary Australians prepared to negotiate on issues related to productivity; ordinary Australians living within the constraints of the workplace act and conforming to the terms of that act.

And the frustration of this government, at least in part, represents the frustration they have with their act and the competence of this minister. Nobody looking at this situation objectively can have anything other than utter contempt for the incompetence with which the industrial relations policies of Patrick have been pursued over the course of the last three or four months—mendacious, incompetent, pathetic, and joined in that by the minister here.

There is going to be a lot of water flow under the bridge on this but every Australian knows this: when it comes to jobs, when it comes to your personal dignity, when it comes to your opportunity to support your family, this government is not in your corner. When it comes to your sense of security, as you sit down to borrow to pay off your house and other debts, this government does not stand in your corner.

When it comes to the opportunity to live the life of an ordinary Australian with some degree of happiness, comfort and certitude about where you are headed, this government does not stand in your corner. When it comes to demanding of your political process basic decency and honesty, and to be governed by a government indifferent to the consequences of their actions because they are fair minded, then everybody in this country knows that this government is not in their corner. When it comes to the basic decent compassion that people expect of government in this nation everybody in this nation knows that this government is not in their corner.

This is a government without a shred of credibility on this. This is a government which invites the Australian people to support a set of actions the like of which has not been seen by any Australian government in recent times. This is a government which stands exposed for its basic deceit. As far as its last election promises are concerned, it is a government that should be condemned. (Time expired)
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Tanner's amendment) stand part of the question.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

debate.para: That the motion (Mr Reith's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative, by an absolute majority.

talk.start.para: —I now put the question that the House has resolved should be put without debate, which also precludes any proposed amendment, namely, that this House supports the introduction of genuine competi tion on the waterfront and the right of all employees, et cetera. The question is that the motion, as proposed in the resolution just agreed to by this chamber, be agreed to.

—On a point of order, Mr Speaker, the minister has not moved his motion. We have had a suspension of standing orders to give him the capacity to read it. He has not chosen to stand and move his motion.

—I accept the motion from the Leader of the House in the circumstances. The question is, however, that, the motion having been passed, that resolution is forthwith put. I have just put the resolution.
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker—
—The motion that has been before the House has been passed by the House by an absolute majority—that is, that the Leader of the House shall move forthwith at the completion of this suspension motion—
—He has not moved it.
—I do uphold that point of order. I believe the Leader of the House should move the motion.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Mr Reith) proposed:

That this House supports the introduction of genuine competition on the waterfront and the right of all employees to join or not to join a union of their choice and the outcomes which will flow from a more efficient, reliable waterfront, including:
(1) creating more exports to help reduce Australia's foreign debt and improve job opportunities for the Australian people;
(2) creating more jobs in manufacturing;
(3) improving the opportunity of small businesses to grow and develop in world markets;
(4) improving the safety of all workplaces on the waterfront; and
(5) fuelling economic growth which will lead to higher living standards for all Australians.

talk.start.para: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker: the motion he moved did not preclude debate.
—There is no capacity for you to move an amendment.

interjection.para: Question put:
That the motion (Mr Reith's ) be agreed to.

para.inline: A division having been called and the bells being rung—

talk.start.para: —The question was that the motion be put without debate; `without debate' excludes any amendment.
—That is not what he said.
—If you move an amendment, it is not debate. Read your standing orders.
—It is the resolution that has been passed by this House. The House has already accepted the motion that it will be moved forthwith and without debate. Therefore, the House has passed the resolution.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: if that is your ruling then the Leader of the House should have moved that way. He should have included in his motion the words `without debate'. He did not. Therefore, the only motion that is currently before the House is the one which he has just alluded to, to which we are perfectly entitled to move an amendment.
—He failed to move it correctly. All he got was a suspension of standing orders to move the motion.
—I think the division should be called off, Mr Speaker.
—That is exactly right. Twinkle toes has failed again.

interjection.para: Mr Crean interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The honourable member will withdraw that remark, thank you very much.
—I withdraw it.

—I have been taking advice because in my view the resolution passed by the House has precluded the Leader of the Opposition from moving an amendment. I believe that to be so and I therefore uphold the ruling that the Leader of the Opposition cannot move an amendment where the House has determined that the question should be put without debate.
—I move dissent from your ruling.
—You cannot do so at this stage. You can do it afterwards.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I understand the Leader of the Opposition intends to move a dissent from my ruling. I will repeat my ruling: the House, having carried the introductory part of the motion moved by the Leader of the House—that is from `That so much' down to `suspension motion and without debate'—it was only necessary for the Leader of the House to move part of the motion that commenced `That this House' finishing up with `for all Australians'. Therefore, the motion having just been passed, that motion is carried.
—Just before the Leader of the Opposition does that, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—I understand the Leader of the Opposition intends to move a dissent from my ruling. I will repeat my ruling: the House, having carried the introductory part of the motion moved by the Leader of the House—that is from `That so much' down to `suspension motion and without debate'—it was only necessary for the Leader of the House to move part of the motion that commenced `That this House' finishing up with `for all Australians'. Therefore, the motion having just been passed, that motion is carried.
—Just before the Leader of the Opposition does that, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—We half welcome to this place the first manifestation of the Reith government; no, sorry, the second manifestation of the Reith government. I move:

speech.para: That Mr Speaker's ruling be dissented from.

There is only one particular suspension of standing orders that is acceptable in this place—that is, the motion to suspend standing orders. Then the subsequent motions which are placed before this chamber are motions which are placed before this chamber to deal with it. There is no provision in standing orders to suspend under certain conditions. There is no provision whatsoever to do that. The only provision that lies there is the basic suspension of standing orders.
