It would, of course, be possible for the minister to assure himself that the matter could be deliberated upon without debate simply by gagging debate on the subject.

But I do find it passing strange that the government in these circumstances has decided that they do not want debate on that motion. They have said that they are inordinately proud of their work here this day, that they are inordinately proud of what they have done to ordinary people in this country, that they think they have had a terrific outcome as far as ordinary people in this country are concerned and that we ought to in this place provide opportunities for one after another to stand up and say why they thought it was such a good idea.

One of the cardinal elements of accountability in this place is that we should be able to debate matters of substantial importance. What this government has wanted us to pass without debate and then foolishly failed to move in the appropriate fashion was that this House support the introduction of genuine competition on the waterfront and so on.

Any point here is imminently debateable in this place as to whether the course of action this government has gone down is a course of action that this country would prefer or a course of action that this parliament ought to approve of. For them to stand in this place and move that a matter should be considered without debate is an absolute abdication of their preparedness to defend themselves in this place. It is of a piece with their indefensible actions over the last six to nine months when people in this country have been persistently and deliberately misled.

They think themselves smart on this matter. They think themselves smart that they have no relationship of integrity with the Australian people. They think themselves smart that they can trick Australian people out of their jobs. They think themselves smart that they can approach this issue on this occasion on this day with minimal public consideration of what they are up to.

Mr Speaker, you cannot allow a suspension of standing orders to be used to permit such action to take place—to forbid, as you effectively do, the capacity to move an amendment to a motion before the House. That is unprecedented—to remove the capacity to move an amendment to a motion before this House; an amendment which, if we had had the capacity to move it, would have indicated a whole variety of concerns on our part for the 1,400 workers who have been sacked—the 1,400 workers, many of whom have never been on strike; many of whom are in ports which have, in the memories of any person in this House, not been on strike; many of whom have sat down in successive efforts to improve efficiency on the waterfront, and delivered.

I think of the workers in Townsville, who have quadrupled their productivity over the last four years. According to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), they are being punished—not because they have been regular strikers, not because they have been in confrontation with their employer, not because they have committed acts of inefficiency, not because they have been rorting, but for one reason only: they are members of a union.

When this Prime Minister supported the introduction of this Industrial Relations Bill, when the industrial relations minister introduced his Industrial Relations Bill, when we pointed out that the object of this Industrial Relations Bill was to deprive workers of freedom of choice, we were told, `You are talking nonsense. Choice is what we are about; workers can choose to be in unions, or they can reject the option of being in unions; workers can choose to collectively bargain, or they can reject the option of collective bargaining; workers can choose to be protected by awards and an enterprise bargaining process, or they can choose to have individual agreements. All their rights are protected. Australians love freedom. Australians love an opportunity to have a choice. That is all we stand for.' Then calumny is heaped on the union movement, calumny is heaped on those who want to collectively bargain; nevertheless, they have that choice.

What has been revealed today is that there is no choice. The choice exists only in so far as the government are prepared to permit it, and no further. If they choose that you do not have the right to collectively bargain, if they choose that you do not have the right to exercise freedom of association, if they—

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Leader of the Opposition is moving a dissent from your ruling. In his contribution to the debate, he is discussing the question of the previous resolution before the House. He really must confine his remarks to areas where the ruling is inappropriate.
—The Leader of the Opposition is ranging fairly wide, but I think he has licence to do so in the present circumstances.

—I thank the Speaker for that ruling. What I was, in fact, referring to—and I thank you for your licence in this regard, Mr Speaker—was the amendment that I was unable to move because of the set of circumstances from which we are dissenting. The reason why I would be moving that amendment, were we to have the chance, would be the failure of the minister to move his motion in the appropriate form, having been given permission by the parliament to do so, correctly interpreted by yourself, and therefore providing us with the opportunity to do that. As I was saying before being interrupted—and as would have been covered in the amendment that we would have moved, had your ruling permitted us to do so—those workers have had their capacity of freedom of association ripped away from them.

speech.para: The Prime Minister stands in this place and thumbs his nose at these ordinary working Australians and says, `You're being punished for the activities of somebody else; well, serves you right.' What sort of community operates on that basis? What sort of community allows freedom of association to be ripped away by the whim of a Prime Minister? What security is there for anyone?

When you look at a dictatorship created, what you see is a step by step process by which your rights and freedoms are ripped away from you. The things that have made a particular nation, with democratic practice at the heart and core of its culture, are ripped away from you. That is what happens, and that is precisely what has happened in this instance—they have been absolutely ripped away from them.

talk.start.para: —What about compelling people to join a union?
—The member who is interjecting on me talks of compulsion and competition. This motion which we have debated talks about competition. What competition, my friend, is being permitted at Dampier?

speech.para: There has been an action at that great exporting port of Dampier—a far more significant exporting port than Adelaide, a far more significant exporting port than Brisbane. What has happened at that port? P&O have been deprived of their rights to operate in that port. A monopoly has been established on one basis and one basis only: that those who agree to be participants in the work force of that monopoly do not join a union. That is the basis on which that proposition has been involved. Because the workers of P&O exercised their right to join a union, to collectively bargain, not only were they removed from the waterfront—so was P&O.

This is not a small incident, old son. This happens to be a major issue. This happens to be what this government is supposed to be talking about in relation to competition. P&O said, `Okay, we've lost the contract. Can we come on and compete? Can we come onto the Dampier waterfront and compete with this non-union operation that has been put in in place of us?' No. And does this government support it? Yes. This government, which is supposedly about competition, says, `Bully for you, Western Australian government; get on with it.'

This is the freedom of association that you support. This is the freedom for ordinary, individual Australians exercising their conscience that you have supported. That is what you have associated yourself with in this regard. It is very much to your detriment that you have done so. It speaks ill of you that you have chosen to do so.

There is a much more complicated picture around the Australian waterfront than that which is being portrayed here. When you look at the operations of Patricks and compare them with the operations of P&O—because this motion here talks about competition—you find various things.

There is a competent operation here in Australia being operated by a company that knows basically how to do things, not a company that enjoys good relations all the time with its work force but which actually knows how to operate. Then there is another operation being operated by somebody with no experience of management of anything other than a cash box. The consequence of that is incompetence in management on that waterfront. We have had resignations from supervisory personnel associated with that company pointing out that the lack of productivity is as much a problem of management as it is a problem of that work force.

That work force is to be sacked as far as this particular company is concerned. That work force is to take the blame for their incompetence. That work force is to be fired and replaced. That is what is going to happen as far as they are concerned. This parliament does not have a chance to debate that matter because this parliament had a motion before it which said that a matter would be put forthwith without debate. But, when that motion was actually moved, it was moved in mistaken form by the smart alec associated with it.

There is a situation as far as this country is concerned now where workers' rights are threatened, Australian rights are threatened, and this parliament is precluded from debating the principle motion before it. There is a piece of legislation before this parliament, but after I spoke to it no further discussion could take place upon it. There is now another motion before this House—this particular proposition—and the parliament is denied deliberation on this motion. It was denied deliberation on this motion and would have been denied deliberation on this motion within standing orders if the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) had bothered to move his motion in the correct form, which should have read:
That this House without debate supports the introduction . . .
And so on. That is the correct form in which it should have been moved if it was to be protected from the operations of the standing orders.

That was what that smart alec Leader of the House should have done, because at the end of the day the Speaker is in a situation where he has to make a very quick interpretation of what actually happens in this place. If the Speaker was well served by his Leader of the House, on this occasion what the Leader of the House would have done was this: he would have moved his motion `that this House supports without debate the introduction' and so on of what he called genuine competition. He failed to do that and he let his Speaker down when he moved in that way. The consequence of letting his Speaker down when he moved in that way was to put this parliament in a situation where we now have to deliberate on a dissent motion in relation to the Speaker's ruling.

It is necessary to deal with that dissent motion in relation to the Speaker's ruling because what we are confronting here is an action which Australians must contemplate. There has been so much deceit in the presentation of this issue in this place. Part of that deceit has gone, for example, to the alleged cost of stevedoring operations as far as the waterfront is concerned. We had the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) standing up here and stating the enormous burden that is imposed upon rural imports. The cost of stevedoring charges for a kilo of beef is about 1¼c. That is the cost of stevedoring charges on a kilo of beef.

There was a time when the farmers had genuinely legitimate claims against people on the waterfront. The relationships between the farming community and those on the waterfront were utterly poisonous. The hardworking farmers of this nation were being massively frustrated. That was one of the reasons why, when we took up the Howard-Fraser mess on the waterfront—the massively overmanned waterfront with the horrendous work practices across the board—that had sat there for years with a cheerio show from the Liberal Party just letting it pass through, we firstly went to bulk cargo. We went to the bulk of goods that moved across that waterfront; two-thirds of the goods that moved across that waterfront. We went to them. What did we say? We said, `Fix it.' And they fixed it.

They produced world best practice, sufficient world best practice for the minister to be able to stand at the dispatch box earlier today and say, unattributed, `We do not have to make provision for sacking any workers involved with bulk cargo'—although I think there is a question mark over that, quite frankly—`because we have world best practice.' It was just a slight sentence that passed. He just dismissed as irrelevant two-thirds of what goes on on the Australian waterfront with the words, `That is world best practice.' Two-thirds of what passes across the Australian waterfront goes with world best practice. Then we have the situation which is being dealt with here. What is going on in Patrick at the moment—or at least until last night—was an enterprise bargaining process.

talk.start.para: —Asset stripping.

—The honourable member for Shortland also points out that what was going on in Patrick was asset stripping. That was also going on as far as Patrick was concerned. What was also going on, apart from asset stripping by the management, was an enterprise bargaining process which has been available and which has already produced a 40 per cent improvement in productivity on the waterfront—a 40 per cent improvement on productivity on the waterfront.

interjection.para: There is more needed to be done. Who admitted that more needed to be done? Those workers on the waterfront as well as management. Who was prepared to discuss better productivity? Those workers on the waterfront with management. What were they doing with Patrick? They were discussing productivity change with Patrick. What Patrick did not want to do was to arrive at a conclusion. Patrick have not been motivated by any outcome other than the destruction of the union. That has been the only outcome.

A product of destruction of the union is the destruction of ordinary Australians' rights—ordinary Australians' rights which we fought two world wars to have held in place. Do not kid yourself that that was not an issue in those two conflicts. What we valued in this country above all was that we were different. What we valued in this country above all was that Jack was as good as his master. Part of Jack being as good as his master is that Jack had freedom of choice. Jack was able to take a decision about whether or not he wanted to bargain with his master as an individual or bargain with his master with his friends. That is what we had in this country and we were proud of it. We saw it as central to democracy.

I remember when I was first elected to this place that both sides of the House were standing with Solidarity in Poland, and both sides of this House were waving banners for ILO conventions on freedom of association. Both sides of this House were booting the Soviets right up the bracket for their Communist dictatorship suppression of workers' rights. But somewhere along the way to the forum, the other side of the House got mugged. Somewhere along the way to the forum, the standards that they used to uphold in criticism of totalitarian regimes were stuck in the back pocket. They stuck them in the back pocket here today with the legislation they have introduced in this place and the motivation that they have associated with their resolutions.

Because of the Speaker's incorrect ruling in not upholding our point of order on that, dictated by the failure of the Leader of the House to move his motion appropriately and to include the words `that this House supports without debate the introduction', and so on, we have not had the opportunity to point these things out. We have not had the opportunity that a parliament ought to have to deliberate on these things. It does no harm to this parliament to be able to deliberate on these matters. In fact, it is essential that we do. Unless this relevant dissent motion is carried, we simply will not have that opportunity.

talk.start.para: —Is the motion seconded?

—I second the motion. I will not take the full time, because I will have an opportunity to speak on the MPI, which the government has assured us we will still have. This dissent goes to the very purpose of why we assemble here in the parliament. It is about accountability. It seems to be absolutely clear that you cannot lose your right to debate in this House without a substantive resolution. You cannot lose your right to debate just caught up in a resolution about suspension of standing orders.

speech.para: The resolution before us has three action points in it. The first is about the suspension of standing orders. The second is about the substantive motion. The third is that that substantive motion should be discussed without debate. We could have dealt with it in two resolutions—one to suspend and one to say, `Without debate we should consider the following resolution.' But we cannot in one resolution both suspend the standing orders and take away from the whole of the House—but effectively from this side of the House, and from the Independents who wanted to raise points of order—the right to debate a very fundamental issue.

What an issue it is. It goes to the very liberties of the citizens. The parliament and its freedom of speech is at its core for the defence of the liberties of the citizens. What a motion we had today, relating to the liberties of, at the moment, 1,400 Australian citizens. But, in terms of principle, it relates to nine million Australian citizens who work as employees in this country. All of them have their rights at stake in the nature of the debate we are having, or sought to have. If we had been able to move an amendment to this resolution, we would have been able to debate it.

Had the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) been able to move an amendment, we could have addressed this resolution, and we would have been able to talk about the conditions under which we would have been prepared to consider such a resolution. We would have been able to consider issues of whether the workers being sacked was in accordance with the law, whether it was lawful; it needs to be in accordance with the awards and the agreements which employers have entered into.

We would have wanted to say something about the alternative routes by which a decent government would go about seeking to achieve the purposes of waterfront reform. This debate in this parliament is not about whether the waterfront ought to be more efficient. It is a debate about whether, in the pursuit of the false goal of waterfront reform by smashing the MUA, we ought be able to take away the protections and securities which ordinary Australian workers have when they go to work. When they go to work they think that, if they have not done anything wrong, at the end of the day they should still have a job. They came into work—they were working—and got sacked. It did not have anything to do with the individual activities of those workers. The individual performance of those 1,400 people was not assessed. Nobody said, `Well, sir, you have not done a very good job.' They got rid of the lot. Why? Mr Corrigan made it very clear: because they were members of the MUA, and he could not get the agreement he wanted.

It is true that some of those people had been on strike. My distinct recollection of the law passed by this parliament is that workers actually have a right to do that. I have always thought that in Australia it is a right we expect people to have and that they can do it in accordance with the proper law. There is no argument even by the government that the strikes that had taken place were lawful. But what we have here is a whole lot of people who were not involved in those strikes. They were just members of the same union whose members thousands of miles away—in a different port, but with the same employer—went on strike about their enterprise agreement.

Of course, we have one port in Australia where the employer signed the enterprise agreement. That was the port of Melbourne. There is an interesting debate about why that was the only place that was signed. It will be debated on another occasion. That agreement said `no compulsory redundancies'. It was signed, and we did not get a chance to talk about that today because of the nature of this ruling.

Not only is it a very worrying principle that we can have the right of members to debate issues taken away without substantive resolution but we also have had it on a question that goes very clearly to the liberties of the citizens and to the circumstance of 1,400 Australian families in the lead-up to Easter. In Sydney, the kids will say, `Can we go to the Royal Easter Show, Dad?' Dad says, `No, I'm sorry; I haven't got a job.' `Are we going to go away on school holidays, Dad; there are two weeks school holidays coming up?' `No, we can't; Dad's just lost his job.' But we cannot talk about it in here. What a happy Easter that is for the 1,400 Australian families who are affected by the matters that we have been dealing with today!

It is not the attitude that most Australians think should take us into the Easter break. It is not the way in which most Australians think we should deal with Easter. It is not the way most Australians think we should deal with the rights of Australians; and your ruling, Mr Speaker, is not the way I believe we should deal with the rights of members in this place to speak up on behalf of their constituents.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, the government will support you in your ruling. It is absolutely indisputably a correct ruling and it should be upheld by this House, by all people of honour in this place. On occasions, Mr Speaker, you are called upon to exercise great wisdom in interpreting standing orders when you are challenged, often in a very unruly manner, in relation to the rulings that you have made. Sometimes those decisions can be difficult, sometimes maybe even open to interpretation, but in this case I would submit that your ruling was simple, it was easy to make and it was utterly and absolutely correct.

speech.para: The Speaker's ruling in this instance upheld the specific decision of the House. You were left with no discretion. The House decided that this particular matter would not be debated and you upheld the decision that the House made. In that regard, your decision was absolutely correct. It might be that this procedure was a little unusual in that the House would decide, in discussing a suspension motion, that the matter that would be dealt with after the suspension would not be the subject of debate. That might be unusual but it was certainly within the capacity of the House to make that decision—and it did so. It made the decision completely and appropriately. Once that decision was made, your ruling was absolutely correct to uphold the decision of the House and to proceed immediately with the vote on the motion moved by the Leader of the House (Mr Reith).

It is not as though the decision that the House made was one to deny debate on this issue. There have been plenty of opportunities for debate. In fact, there is to be a matter of public importance to follow which will provide the opposition with yet another opportunity to contribute on this particular issue. The day began with an opportunity that was given by the House this morning to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) at 9.30 when the bills were introduced to speak to the House. We provided that opportunity. We could have easily allowed the normal procedures to follow; in other words, the debate be adjourned immediately and the Leader of the Opposition and other opposition members who wished to speak have that opportunity when the second reading debate came before the House. We did not adopt that normal procedure. We granted indulgence to the Leader of the Opposition to give him an immediate opportunity to reply.

Then we came to question time today, a time when the opposition normally have 10 questions to put to the House on matters of concern to them. Did they take that opportunity then to raise 10 matters in relation to the waterfront? No. It was such a low priority in their own mind that they ran out of steam after only four waterfront questions, and then they went on to other subjects, which clearly demonstrated that their own priorities in that regard were not so high. So there was plenty of opportunity.

Then came the motion of quite some substance, and I think importance, moved by the Leader of the House. Even on that occasion the opposition were given their chances to reply—and they got more than the opportunity that might normally be available during the suspension debate because they actually moved their amendment. They provided to the House the information of what was going to be proposed in their amendment and the House dealt with that amendment in the process of dealing with the motion calling for the suspension of standing orders.

So there has been plenty of opportunity provided to the opposition and there will be plenty of opportunity provided in the future for them to address this sort of issue. The Speaker in his ruling that the decision of the House should be upheld made the only possible decision that he could make in those circumstances—and the government will certainly be supporting the Speaker in his ruling.

The reality is that the opposition are raising this matter to hide their embarrassment about having just voted in this House against waterfront reform. They ought to be ashamed of having taken this action, trying to vote down the motion—they voted against it—seeking to introduce genuine competition on the waterfront.

The motion that was voted on called for genuine competition on the waterfront. Members opposite, members of the Labor Party, voted in this House just a short time ago against genuine reform on the waterfront. They want the rorts to continue, they want the overmanning to continue, they want the inefficiencies to continue and they want the national embarrassment on our waterfronts to continue. They are against reform.

The next part of the question that they voted against was the right of employees to join or not join a union. Is the honourable member for Canberra (Mr McMullan) actually saying that he voted against a motion acknowledging the right of employees to join a union or not join a union? I think it needs to go on the public record—the people of Australia need to know—that the opposition voted against a motion which gives people the right to join a union or not join a union.

Then the motion went on to refer to the outcomes which would flow from a more efficient and reliable waterfront. The member for Canberra, the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), the opposition spokesman for industry, the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), voted against a whole series of measures which would in fact demonstrate the benefits of an efficient and reliable waterfront.

Is the member for Hotham going to go home to his constituents and explain to them why he voted against reforms to create more exports, to help reduce Australia's foreign debt, to improve job opportunities for the Australian people? The members of the Labor Party have just finished voting against those worthy objectives. They have also voted against creating more jobs in manufacturing. How is the member for Hotham going to explain to his industry constituency why he voted against more jobs in manufacturing?

They also voted against improving the opportunities for small business to grow and develop in world markets. The opposition do not like small business. They have always been against small business. The only thing they do for small business is turn big businesses into small businesses because of their anti-industry policy. They voted against it. They also voted against measures to improve the safety of all workplaces on the waterfront. They are against safety on the waterfront. What an extraordinary decision from the opposition!

Finally, they voted against fuelling economic growth which will lead to higher living standards for all Australians. This is the resolution that the honourable member for Hotham, the honourable member for Canberra and the honourable member for Burke have voted against. Is it any wonder that the opposition are embarrassed? Is it any wonder that the opposition are seeking to dissent from your ruling, Mr Speaker, to try to distract attention from their own actions in voting against reform on the waterfront?

All Australians want to see a more efficient and safer waterfront, except members opposite. All Australians want to create more exports. They want to create more jobs in manufacturing. They want to see small business more profitable. They want to see improved safety on the waterfront. They want to see economic growth. All Australians want that; but the members of the Labor Party voted against it. Is it any wonder that they are ashamed? Is it any wonder that they are trying to distract attention?

They want a waterfront, it seems, that is mocked by the rest of the world. They want to see a waterfront that remains at a level where it is less productive even than places like Manila, Mozambique and New Zealand. They want Australia to remain an international laughing stock. It seems as though the opposition have lost themselves in the mire of these issues, where they could do nothing. They spent $400 million, but achieved nothing in making our waterfront an effective place to work.

This House has just voted to support the introduction of genuine competition on the waterfront. It supported the right of employees to join or not join a union. It supported a more efficient and reliable waterfront. It has voted to support that. But it was not a unanimous vote. There was one group of dinosaurs who decided that they would vote against these important matters of reform—members opposite.

I have not had the privilege of reading in great detail the book by the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). But I think I can be absolutely certain that his book would not have advocated the sorts of policies that were voted against by his colleagues today. In his book, I am sure he would not advocate propositions which would reduce jobs in manufacturing, which would help increase Australia's foreign debt, and which would help make small businesses' life more difficult. Yet he, with his colleagues today, has in fact voted against the various principles that he espoused at the National Press Club only a short time ago and which were supported by the Leader of the Opposition. Their memories are short. They can write books and persuade the gullible public to spend their money on buying the books. But when it comes to actually implementing what is in the books, their attitude is totally different.

Of course, in this particular situation the shame of the opposition will reverberate around the country as it becomes clear that they are standing hand in hand with those who would keep our waterfront inefficient. I wonder quite often, when the member for Canberra and others come into this place and speak in defence of the sorts of practices that have been going on at the waterfront, what they say to the people in the factories, the farms and the industries of Australia who have been struggling hard over a long time to improve their own efficiency. They have endured some pain and hardship to make the industry of Australia more efficient, to have the best farms and the best mines in the world, only to have all of their efforts undermined by the inefficiencies and the rorts on the waterfront, by the overmanning and by the excessive costs of getting things out of our country.

This is a country with a relatively small population that is utterly dependent upon exports if it is to have world-class industry, world-class production and the sorts of costs of production that you achieve through international scale industry. Clearly we can achieve those benefits only if we have an efficient waterfront. That is why the actions of this government in finally taking the sword to many of these unacceptable practices are so commended by the people of Australia. That is why this action is so supported by Australians right from west to east, by all people who believe in a more productive Australia, by all those workers in factories, in the mines and on the farms of Australia who have done their bit, who have made their own contributions towards building a more productive country.

They expect the same from the people who are earning $80,000, $90,000 or $100,000 on the waterfront. I should not use the term `earning'—being paid that amount of money to occupy space on the wharves and hold our exports to ransom. These sorts of things are unacceptable practices. But they are the sorts of things that have just been supported by the opposition. So they hide their shame by seeking to question your perfectly correct ruling on this matter, Mr Speaker.

The reality is that your ruling is absolutely correct. You have upheld the specific decision of this House. The ruling is correct. The decision was made by this House in a democratic way and you, as the upholder of the decisions of this House, have acted perfectly correctly in your ruling. Mr Speaker, I commend you on having ruled absolutely correctly on this issue. The opposition are merely creating a smokescreen by trying to dissent from this particular ruling. They have had their opportunities. They will have plenty more opportunities to discuss these sorts of issues. I commend you on your ruling. The government will be supporting you. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question put:
That the motion (Mr Beazley's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I wish to add to an answer that I gave the honourable member for Curtin during question time today which was in relation to anti-avoidance provisions applying to franking credit trading. The anti-avoidance provisions applying to franking credit trading are separate general anti-avoidance provisions in the franking credit trading and dividend streaming draft legislation. The franking credit trading dividend streaming anti-avoidance rule relates to a tax benefit obtained by other than incidental purposes, as I mentioned. Part 4A, which is a separate part, relies on a sole or dominant purpose for the tax benefit.

speech.para: The proposed new anti-avoidance provisions in the franking credit trading dividend streaming draft legislation will not be triggered merely because a person has acquired or disposed of either Telstra instalment receipts or, upon their conversion, Telstra shares. It will be triggered, as I said earlier, only if there are unusual circumstances accompanying the relevant transactions which demonstrate artificiality or contrivance in commercial features or which appear to stultify the real purpose of share ownership. I thank the House for that opportunity.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Please proceed.

—This morning I was sent a facsimile of an article published in the Prosh newspaper which is distributed by members of the University of Western Australia campus in the run-up to their Prosh week next week. The article is headed `Useless Alan Rocher out for the count'.
—The honourable member needs to show where he has been misrepresented!
—It is peppered with remarks such as `the most pathetic politician since Federation'-

speech.para: Mr Melham interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Hear me out, please. It said that I had `lost the plot upon hearing he cannot contest the next election for the seat of Curtin as a Liberal'. The author went on to say that I am a useless pile of excrement, but he—or she—did not use the word `excrement'. I think the word used is an Anglo-Saxon word of four letters. He goes on to say `all he talks about is tax'. It is peppered with these lines, but I will not bore you with all of them. He does cast reflections on my French heritage when he says, `Alan Rocher, he sounds like a gourmet chocolate.'

speech.para: So far, so good—subtle, constructive, considerate political comment! I have no objection to that. But then the author had the effrontery to write, `He probably can't even play cricket.' Enough is enough; we can only stand so much! I scored my first century in senior cricket at the age of 16. I have trophies—admittedly unpolished—at home for winning batting averages for my clubs. I scored 67 as an opening batsman for the Flotation Cricket Club in the grand final of the West Coast of Tasmania cricket competition in 1957, and paved the way for victory. I play for parliamentary XIs. I secured the wicket of Ross Edwards, an international Australian, with the first ball I ever bowled to him. I had Keith Stackpole dropped at the MCG off the first ball, by Ray Groom—and I will never forgive him.

talk.start.para: —I think the honourable member's prowess is well and truly established.

—If the author of that unforgivable accusation has a skerrick of decency about him, he will publish an unqualified retraction. Might I say that I also extend my best wishes to the students of the University of Western Australia for a successful Prosh next week and thank them for the great support they give to Western Australian charities.

subdebateinfo.title: Presiding Officers Information Technology Advisory Group

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, as you will be aware, there is a committee known as the Presiding Officers Information Technology Advisory Group—or POITAG for short. That committee has performed a valu able bipartisan role over the years to ensure that the IT facilities provided to the parliament are relevant to members' needs. Unfortunately, the committee has met on only two or three occasions during the current parliament and has been unable to play any effective role, even though substantial changes are now taking place in the parliamentary computing environment. Will you now assess this matter and ensure that the committee is able to play an effective role in the near future?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. The field in which that committee inquires is of critical importance in this place, particularly with the concerns we all have about the millennium bug. In those circumstances, having met not only with the honourable member but also with the honourable member for Menzies, I have suggested we might have a meeting in the first week of the budget session, hopefully with the deputy speakers and me, to see how we can best progress the deliberations of the committee. I commend the honourable gentlemen and others who are members of that committee for the work they are undertaking on behalf of us all.

—I have a question to you, Mr Speaker. Without the matter being taken offence to by any member from the other side, today you asked me to withdraw the word `fraud' when I used it. On 12 March 1998, while you were in the chair, the Treasurer said, `He is'—referring to the Leader of the Opposition—`nothing but a fraud.' If it is appropriate for you to draw attention to your concern when we say it without it being raised from the other side of the House, why is it not also appropriate to draw attention to it when they say it?

—It is appropriate for both sides of the House to observe standing order 153 and I draw all members' attention to the context of that particular standing order. Frankly, in the hubbub of this place, there are often words that are said that one does not pick up. I believe that members should not use expressions which in any way are critical of the character or conduct of other persons in this place. Certainly, when I hear such words, it would be my intention as far as possible to stop members doing so.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is becoming increasingly the practice—and I ask for your guidance—for members in this place to ask you for advisorial readings. I seem to recall that, except on odd occasions recently, that has never been the case. I wonder, if that burden is to be heaped on you, whether you might not like to review the precedents that have occurred in this place.

—The honourable member for Curtin is, of course, correct. The Speaker is only required to answer on matters relating to matters of administration and certainly as far as questions under 144 to ministers are concerned. The Speaker cannot be asked for legal opinions. Today I have accepted the questions.

—This question relates to yesterday in this House. The debate got a bit willing but when I came in here on the suspension of standing orders, just after the dinner break, in the middle of the debate the Hansard records the member for Paterson, Mr Bob Baldwin, saying of me, `You've got the political morals of an alley cat.' The Deputy Speaker, Mr Nehl, was in the chair at the time—and this is recorded at page 1879 of Hansard —and the Deputy Speaker in fact warned the member for Paterson. I immediately asked for those words to be withdrawn and for there to be an apology. You might recall, because the member for Swan is in the House at the moment, that he had to come into the place and apologise for using similar words.

question.para: I have raised this with the Deputy Speaker but I am drawing it to your attention because it has not come back to me. I persisted with this but my time was running out and I needed to get some points on the record. The Deputy Speaker at the time said that he could not hear because of the noise but that he had warned the member for Paterson and that that was the only action he intended to take at that moment. My question has been to the Deputy Speaker that, having regard to the record, does he intend, or through you, to require the member for Paterson to withdraw that statement about me, because it is on the record and the record will demonstrate that I asked for it to be withdrawn at the first available opportunity?

talk.start.para: —While I, like you, do not accept that the words were particularly appropriate it does so happen that I turned to Hansard and noted that on 26 May 1983, on 8 December 1983 and on 28 August 1995 the person who was the previous Prime Minister used exactly those words about people who were in the then opposition. Having said that, I do not approve of the words used and had I been here I would certainly have required the member to withdraw them at the time. If the words are not required to be withdrawn at the time there is no procedure available to me other than for me to ask the honourable member, who is not now present in the chamber, to take note of the request from the honourable member and if he so desires he can come in and apologise. I understand there are two or three other questions of a similar character still before the parliament.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order, you made the point about a withdrawal not being required. It was required at the time and the member for Hotham did ask. So this is a situation that is even further enhanced by the request—

—I point out to the honourable member for Banks that, as I understand it, the Deputy Speaker said that he did not hear the words and, as a result, I have put the appropriate solution to the House. In the absence of the member concerned there is no other course available to me.

—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: there have been many occasions on which the Speaker has not heard the words, and I accept that. But on every occasion that I am aware of where the member against whom they have been directed has asked for them to be withdrawn the Speaker of the time has always said, `I did not hear the words but I would ask the member to withdraw.' That did not happen on this occasion. That is what I am also trying to draw to your attention. The Hansard record is clear on what was said, and my request was not pursued.

—I would point out that past Speakers have not done as the honourable member has just suggested. I have a quote from 28 August 1995, on page 583 of the Hansard , where the former Prime Minister, having used those words, said:

answer.para: So what? For someone with the morals of an alley cat . . .
The then Speaker said:
The Prime Minister might just withdraw that comment.
The former Prime Minister then said:
I will withdraw it to emphasise the `So what?' comment . . .

I suggest that there has been a solution proposed. I have suggested to the House that the honourable member for Paterson, if he so wishes, may come into this House and withdraw those words. It is up to him to do so.

talk.start.para: —In the adjournment debate last night you would recall that the member for O'Connor failed to unconditionally withdraw a physical threat against me.

—This is not a question to me. If you wish to pursue matters you do so at the time. The matter has to be processed at the time. I will hear you briefly but the question at the moment is not within the standing orders.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is inappropriate for members of the opposition to use this occasion of questions to you to canvass matters that happened in the past and to argue points of procedure. This period is to ask you questions about matters within your administrative responsibility and I do not believe it is appropriate to keep canvassing rulings endlessly, time and time again, as the opposition have been doing during this period.

—The minister is totally correct. There is no responsibility on me to answer but I am trying hard to ensure that members at least have some opportunity. I suggest the member for Grayndler specifically addresses a question within my responsibility.
—Page 476 of House of Representatives Practice indicates that offensive words will be withdrawn unconditionally. You will recall that last night I said:

question.para: I think this is an eminently reasonable request, which is that the member for O'Connor withdraw the threat unconditionally.
The member for O'Connor withdrew his remarks.

My question to you is this: given that the member for Werriwa was forced to leave the House just two minutes earlier under section 304A for normal interjections, will you ensure that in future such physical threats across the chamber are withdrawn unconditionally?

talk.start.para: —I think the honourable member understands that there is fairly robust debate in this place from time to time. The honourable member for O'Connor did withdraw the remark and I take it as such.

—My question is in a way related to the question raised by the honourable member for Bonython. As you are aware, members have Internet access in their offices at Parliament House. However, when they return to their electorate offices, in the main they cannot respond to the e-mail messages that frequently hit their computers. You, for one, Mr Speaker, have encouraged the use of technology in this place but our inability to reply—to almost rudely fail to respond—to these messages leaves us very poorly placed. Those who have Internet access in their electorate offices have a receive facility only, which makes it doubly frustrating. Could you review the present situation—and I understand that cost is part of the problem—and advise the House and members when relief from this situation may be available?

—I share the honourable gentleman's concern. It is one of the questions I thought I might raise at the committee of which the honourable member for Bonython is a member when we meet in that first week. I take on board the question and will see what can be done. Like you, I feel it is unacceptable that we do not have an outward connection through Internet.

—I present a report from KPMG, the internal auditor of the Department of the House of Representatives, on that firm's audit of members' travelling allowances for the period 1 July 1995 to 30 June 1997. The report follows a progress report relating to the 1995-96 period tabled by Speaker Halverson on 18 November 1997. The auditor has concluded:

speech.para: The overwhelming majority of travelling allowance records are fully supported by independently collected travel records of flight information, car hire, taxi hire and fuel purchases.

Twenty-two thousand, two hundred and eighteen travelling allowance records for members and former members were matched against travel records held by the former Department of Administrative Services and other travel records. As part of this process, members and former members have been approached by the auditors not because of perceived errors in their claims but pursuant to the normal audit process.

As at 3 April 1998, 22,205 records or 99.9 per cent were reconciled, leaving 13 outstanding. These remaining records were unable to be reconciled because information was not available from a member and former members. Two hundred and eighteen travelling allowance records or 0.98 per cent were found to be in error, of which 168 were overpayments and 50 were underpayments. It is currently anticipated that net recoveries arising from the audit will total $20,825. This amount represents 0.62 per cent of total expenditure on travel allowances by the Department of the House of Representatives for the two years 1 July 1995 to 30 June 1997.
The outcome of the audit confirms the overall integrity of members and the Department of House of Representatives in the processing of travel entitlements.

talk.start.para: —I present the Auditor-General's audit report No. 39 for 1997-98 entitled Performance audit—Management of selected junctions of the Child Support Agency .

interjection.para: Motion (by Mr Truss) agreed to:
That:
(1) this House authorises the publication of the Auditor-General's audit report No. 39 of 1997-98; and
(2) the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —Papers are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the papers will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings and Hansard.

speech.para: The schedule read as follows—
Electoral Matters—Joint Standing Committee—Report—The 1996 federal election: Inquiry into the conduct of the 1996 federal election and matters related thereto—Government response.
Endangered Species Protection Act—1998 review—
Report by Dr N. Keith Boardman.
